subject: linear_algebra
title: Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors Defined
contentHtml:
Eigenvalues and eigenvectors are fundamental concepts in linear algebra that help us understand how matrices transform vectors.

Geometrically, an eigenvector of a matrix is a non-zero vector that, when transformed by the matrix, gets scaled or reflected without changing direction. The corresponding eigenvalue represents this scaling factor.
intuition: Think of eigenvectors as special directions in which a matrix has no effect, and the eigenvalues represent how much each direction gets scaled.
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, eigenvectors are used to reduce dimensionality and identify patterns in data
commonMistakes: Don't confuse eigenvectors with null vectors; they're not the same thing.

title: Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors Defined
contentHtml:
Eigenvalues and eigenvectors are fundamental concepts in linear algebra that help us understand how matrices transform vectors.

Geometrically, an eigenvector is a non-zero vector that, when transformed by the matrix, gets scaled by its corresponding eigenvalue. In other words, if \[Av = \lambda v\], then v is an eigenvector and \lambda is its eigenvalue.
